user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SelectFdAdd:
```c
int32 OS_SelectFdAdd(OS_FdSet *Set, osal_id_t objid)
{
    int32        return_code;
    osal_index_t local_id;

    /* check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(Set);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM, objid, &local_id);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * Sets the bit in the uint8 object_ids array that corresponds
         * to the local_id where local_id >> 3 determines the array element,
         * and the mask/shift sets the bit within that element.
         */
        Set->object_ids[local_id >> 3] |= 1 << (local_id & 0x7);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SelectFdAdd:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
typedef struct
{
    uint8 object_ids[(OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES + 7) / 8];
} OS_FdSet
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_index_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM 0x06
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No language extensions are used in the provided code fragment. The code only uses standard C constructs: typedefs (int32_t/uint8/uint32), macros, array indexing, bitwise and shift operators, integer literals and standard function-style return. There are no compiler-specific keywords or extensions present (e.g. __attribute__, __asm, typeof, statement expressions, inline assembly, variable-length array extensions, designated initializers with nonstandard syntax, or other documented compiler extensions). The OS_CHECK_POINTER macro expands to a BUGCHECK(...) call, but the BUGCHECK definition is not provided; nothing in the visible expansion uses a compiler extension. Therefore no fragments from the shown code need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
